title: Problem Overview
content: **Random Power Series on the Unit Circle.** Imagine flipping a coin for each term of a power series to decide its sign. Erdős asked: even when the series diverges at most points on the unit circle, must it still converge somewhere? Michelen and Sawhney (2025) proved yes — and the convergence set is surprisingly large, with Hausdorff dimension 1.
mathContext: Given aₙ ∈ ℝ with Σ|aₙ|² = ∞ and |aₙ| = o(1/√n), and random signs εₙ = ±1, does Σ εₙaₙzⁿ converge for some |z| = 1 a.s.? Answer: YES, and the convergence set has Hausdorff dimension 1.

title: Core Definitions
content: **The building blocks:** unitCircle is {z ∈ ℂ : |z| = 1}. littleO_sqrt captures the decay condition |aₙ| = o(1/√n) — coefficients must shrink faster than 1/√n. divergentSquares means Σ|aₙ|² = ∞, ensuring the series has enough energy. randomPowerSeries builds the series εₙaₙzⁿ, and convergesAt checks if it is summable at a given point z.
mathContext: littleO_sqrt(a) := ∀ ε > 0, ∃ N, ∀ n ≥ N, |a n| < ε/√n. divergentSquares(a) := ¬Summable(n ↦ (a n)²). These two conditions together are the hypotheses of Erdős's question.

title: Probabilistic Setup
content: **Random sign choices** are modeled as fair coin flips. signMeasure is the product probability measure on {±1}^ℕ — each εₙ is independently +1 or -1 with probability 1/2. almostAllSigns(P) means P holds with probability 1 under this measure.
mathContext: signMeasure is axiomatized as a MeasureTheory.Measure on (ℕ → ℤ). almostAllSigns(P) := ∃ S, signMeasure(Sᶜ) = 0 ∧ ∀ ε ∈ S, P(ε). This is the standard probability-1 condition.

title: Classical Divergence Results
content: **Why convergence is surprising.** When Σ|aₙ|² = ∞, the series diverges for almost every z on the unit circle, for almost every sign choice. Even more strikingly, Dvoretzky and Erdős (1959) proved that if |aₙ| > c/√n, the series diverges at EVERY point on the circle. This establishes |aₙ| = o(1/√n) as the sharp threshold.
mathContext: divergence_typical: for a.e. signs, diverges for a.e. z (Lebesgue measure on S¹). dvoretzky_erdos_1959: |aₙ| > c/√n for large n implies divergence at all z ∈ S¹ for a.e. signs. The decay condition is necessary and sharp.

title: Michelen-Sawhney (2025): The Solution
content: **The breakthrough:** Michelen and Sawhney proved that under Erdős's conditions, for almost every sign choice, the convergence set is not just nonempty but has Hausdorff dimension 1. This means the convergence set is geometrically as large as the entire circle (dimension 1) even though it has Lebesgue measure zero. A rich fractal set of convergence points exists despite near-universal divergence.
mathContext: michelen_sawhney_2025: almostAllSigns(ε ↦ (convergenceSet a ε).Nonempty). hausdorff_dimension_one: almostAllSigns(ε ↦ dimH(convergenceSet a ε) = 1). These resolve Problem #527 after 60+ years.

title: Boundary Conditions
content: **What happens at the edge?** When |aₙ| = Θ(1/√n) (the boundary case), behavior is more subtle and depends on the constant. Stronger decay like |aₙ| = O(1/√(n log n)) improves convergence properties. The result does not require monotonicity of the sequence |aₙ|.
mathContext: These axioms mark open boundary questions: the exact behavior when |aₙ| ~ c/√n is not fully understood. The monotonicity condition is not needed for the main theorem.

title: Convergence Set Properties
content: **A fractal phenomenon:** The convergence set has three remarkable properties simultaneously: (1) Hausdorff dimension 1 — geometrically as large as the circle; (2) Lebesgue measure zero — invisible to standard measurement; (3) uncountable — far richer than any discrete set. This combination is characteristic of fractal sets.
mathContext: hausdorffDim wraps Mathlib's dimH. convergence_set_uncountable: the set is uncountable. convergence_set_measure_zero: Lebesgue measure of the convergence set is 0. Dimension 1 + measure 0 = fractal.

title: Concrete Examples
content: **The canonical sequence** aₙ = 1/(√n log n) satisfies both hypotheses: Σ 1/(n(log n)²) = ∞ (divergent squares) and 1/(√n log n) = o(1/√n) (the decay condition). The boundary sequence aₙ = 1/√n fails the decay condition, while aₙ = 1/n has convergent squares. These examples clarify the sharp boundary.
mathContext: example_seq(n) = 1/(√n · log n) for n ≥ 2, else 0. Satisfies both divergentSquares and littleO_sqrt. The sequence 1/√n fails littleO_sqrt; the sequence 1/n fails divergentSquares.

title: Connections, Techniques, and Applications
content: **Rich mathematical context.** Random power series connect to Rademacher functions (the building blocks of random analysis), Khintchine's inequality (relating Lp norms of random sums to l2 norms), and the classical work of Salem-Zygmund and Kahane on random trigonometric series. Michelen-Sawhney's proof uses oscillation analysis, metric entropy (counting covering sets), and martingale methods from probability. Applications include lacunary series, natural boundaries of analytic continuation, and random Fourier analysis.
mathContext: Placeholder axioms for: Rademacher functions rₙ(t) = sign(sin(2ⁿπt)), Khintchine inequality ‖Σ εₙaₙ‖_p ~ (Σ|aₙ|²)^(1/2), and proof techniques (oscillation, metric entropy, martingales). These represent deep connections to probability and harmonic analysis.

title: Summary: SOLVED
content: **Two proved theorems.** erdos_527_main proves the convergence set is nonempty almost surely (direct application of michelen_sawhney_2025). erdos_527_strong proves the convergence set has Hausdorff dimension 1 almost surely (from hausdorff_dimension_one). Problem #527 is SOLVED after 60+ years.
